title: Familial Adenomatous Polyposis Prophylactic Colectomy
setup_script: A 22-year-old woman with known familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) presents for consultation. She has hundreds of adenomatous polyps throughout the colon on surveillance colonoscopy. She is otherwise healthy and has not developed symptoms.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Explain genetics and natural history of FAP including nearly 100% risk of colon cancer by age 40.
Review previous endoscopic findings and any extra-colonic manifestations (duodenal polyps, desmoid tumors).
Discuss surgical options: total abdominal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA) versus proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA).
Consider factors influencing choice: number of rectal polyps, sphincter function, patient lifestyle, fertility concerns.
Obtain preoperative evaluation including nutrition assessment and counseling about fertility and pregnancy.
Plan prophylactic surgery; decide on laparoscopic restorative proctocolectomy with J-pouch to eliminate risk of rectal cancer.
Explain operative steps: total proctocolectomy, construction of ileal pouch, and diverting loop ileostomy.
Perform surgery laparoscopically; ensure adequate mesenteric length and tension-free anastomosis.
Postoperative care: monitor fluid status, stoma, and early feeding; manage pain and DVT prophylaxis.
Educate patient on stoma care and schedule for ileostomy closure after 8-12 weeks following pouch test.
Arrange screening for duodenal and periampullary adenomas and management of desmoid tumors.
Provide genetic counseling for family planning and encourage testing of at-risk relatives.

critical_decision_points: Counseling on cancer risk and prophylactic surgery options in FAP.
Choosing between IRA and IPAA based on rectal disease burden and patient factors.
Executing restorative proctocolectomy with pouch creation and temporary diversion.
Postoperative care and timing of stoma reversal.
Long-term surveillance for extra-colonic manifestations and genetic counseling.
